QA.html
Chapter 2 Quality assurance

Chapter 2 Quality assurance To check for outliers in length measurements, we plotted the distribution of raw length measurements by age and sex against different percentiles of the World Health Organization child growth standard distribution. The majority of observations fell within 3 standard deviations of the mean of the standard for males and females. There were certain cohorts, such as COHORTs Guatemala, that had a larger proportion of observations outside of 3 standard deviations from the mean. There was a higher variability of length measurements in the PROBIT, ZVITAMBO, and Keneba cohorts.
severe-stunting.html
Chapter 3 Severe stunting analyses 3.1 Age-specific severe stunting prevalence 3.2 Age-specific severe stunting incidence

Chapter 3 Severe stunting analyses Below, we display plots for the age-specific prevalence and cumulative incidence of severe stunting (LAZ < -3). Overall, the patterns are the same as for stunting (LAZ < -2), with the peak in prevalence at ages 18-24 months and the highest incidence proportion from 0-3 months. 3.1 Age-specific severe stunting prevalence 3.2 Age-specific severe stunting incidence
secular-trends.html
Chapter 4 Assessment of potential secular trends

Chapter 4 Assessment of potential secular trends This study included cohorts that measured child growth from 1969 to 2014. To assess potential secular trends, we plotted the mean length-for-age Z-score (LAZ) over time. The plot below shows the individual observations from included studies over this range of years. There does not appear to be a secular trend in LAZ.
age-meas.html
Chapter 5 Analyses of age at first measurement 5.1 Histogram of first measurement within age 0-30 days 5.2 Histogram of age at enrollment

Chapter 5 Analyses of age at first measurement Our analyses of stunting incidence assumed that children whose first measurement occurred after birth were assumed to have experienced stunting onset at the age halfway between birth and the first measurement. To assess the extent to which this assumption influenced our estimates, we plotted the distribution of age at first measurement and the age at enrollment. The vast majority of children were enrolled close to birth, and the majority were less than 5 days of age at their first measurement. 5.1 Histogram of first measurement within age 0-30 days 5.1.1 All cohorts 5.1.2 Cohort-stratified 5.2 Histogram of age at enrollment 5.2.1 All cohorts 5.2.2 Cohort-stratified

Chapter 6 Comparison to DHS surveys from matching countries In the manuscript, we compared the mean length-for-age Z-score by age and region in our included studies and in Demographic and Health Survey (DHS) datasets from the same countries as those included in our study. exclude-PROBIT.html
Chapter 8 Primary analyses excluding the PROBIT study 8.1 Mean length-for-age Z-score by age 8.2 Age-specific prevalence 8.3 Age-specific incidence

Chapter 8 Primary analyses excluding the PROBIT study Only one cohort from Europe met the inclusion criteria for this study – the PROBIT study. To assess whether inclusion of this study altered our overall study inference, we repeated analyses excluding the PROBIT cohort, as shown below in the “Overall” panels. Results were very similar with and without the PROBIT cohort. Stunting prevalence was slightly higher at birth, and 8.1 Mean length-for-age Z-score by age 8.1.1 Including PROBIT 8.1.2 Excluding PROBIT 8.2 Age-specific prevalence 8.2.1 Including PROBIT 8.2.2 Excluding PROBIT 8.3 Age-specific incidence 8.3.1 Including PROBIT 8.3.2 Excluding PROBIT

fixed-effects.html
Chapter 10 Sensitivity analysis using fixed effects 10.1 Age-specific prevalence 10.2 Age-specific incidence 10.3 Changes in stunting status by age 10.4 Linear growth velocity

Chapter 10 Sensitivity analysis using fixed effects The primary analyses presented in this manuscript pooled across individual studies using random effects. Inferences about estimates from fixed effects models are restricted to only the included studies.1 The random effects approach was more conservative in the presence of study heterogeneity, as evidenced by larger confidence intervals around each point estimates. Overall, the inference from results produced by each method was similar. 10.1 Age-specific prevalence 10.1.1 Random effects 10.1.2 Fixed effects [ADD CAPTION] 10.2 Age-specific incidence 10.2.1 Random effects 10.2.2 Fixed effects [ADD CAPTION] 10.3 Changes in stunting status by age 10.3.1 Random effects 10.3.2 Fixed effects [ADD CAPTION] 10.4 Linear growth velocity 10.4.1 Random effects 10.4.2 Fixed effects [ADD CAPTION] Hedges, L.
